title: Chaining to a read-only upstream crashes with Errno 30

labels.name: triage
labels.description: The issue needs to be prioritized

body:
TL;DR: It seems that I **can not** chain to a read-only tree.

---

I build spack trees with a fairly set of packages; once built I consider them immutable.

One of my work situations involves AWS instances with a shared EFS filesystem that has horrible performance.  I'd like to build my trees in the EFS filesystem so that they're easily available but they'd take *forever*.

My current solution is to build them at their proper path but in isolation (e.g. in a Docker container), save the tree as a squashfs `.sqsh` file, copy the `.sqsh` file into the shared filesystem (one big file, performance is acceptable), and then use a loopback mount to make it available in its proper location (mounts managed via autofs).

It's a bunch of parts but they line up nicely end-to-end so the complexity isn't overwhelming.

In the end it works nicely and my "immutable" trees are truly read-only.  But....

It seems that I **can not** chain to a read-only tree.

If I:

- clone another copy of my spack repository;
- add an `etc/spack/upstreams.yaml` like so:

  ```yaml
  upstreams:
    spack-instance-1:
      install_tree: /blaheng/env/release/0.1.0
  ```

I end up with this:

```shellsession
$ . share/spack/setup-env.sh
$ spack find
==> Error: [Errno 30] Read-only file system: '/blaheng/env/release/0.1.0/.spack-db'
```

Disabling locks doesn't help:

```shellsession
$ spack --disable-locks find
==> Error: Refusing to disable locks: spack is group-writable.
Running a shared spack without locks is unsafe. You must restrict permissions on /blah/blort/tmp/spack-readonly-bug or enable locks.
$ chmod 755 .
$ spack --disable-locks find
==> Error: [Errno 30] Read-only file system: '/blaheng/env/release/0.1.0/.spack-db'
$
```

I ran the demo commands above with a slightly mismatched {up,down}stream pair of trees:

```shellsession
$ ./bin/spack --version
0.14.1-1934-cefb4ba01
$ /blaheng/env/release/0.1.0/bin/spack --version
0.14.2
```

I'm working on building a standard 'env' tree that up to date w.r.t. this tree and will revisit this.  I've seen the problem with a couple of different version pairings so I'm fairly confident that it's the mis-pairing is not the problem.
